title: What is the most important math course in college? That is used in all career fields. - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t think there’s any math course that’s used in all career fields. For example, my sister is a lawyer. I’m sure she does some arithmetic in her job, but that’s about it. I doubt she ever does any significant algebra, although I will try to remember to ask her the next time we talk because now I’m curious. That said, I think it’s fair to say that the absolute, bare-minimum level of mathematical competence that every college graduate should have is basic algebra. Even if you don’t need to use it in your daily life or career, if you can’t understand it, I don’t think you can call yourself an educated person, and it’s hard to think you’re worthy of a bachelor’s degree. The course that seems to open up the most possibilities, though, is calculus. You can’t really do much in economics, physics, or statistics without it, whereas with it, you can do quite a bit.

Basic algebra. Of course, most physics & engineering majors start off with calculus, but nearly all majors need algebra followed by statistics. Technically even those “studies” courses! Edit: my point is that almost any career that requires a college education will need basic algebra as it foundation. Most technician (AAS) degrees are not calculus-based, but engineering will require calculus. It was also pointed out, if you didn’t sleep in school, you should have a firm grasp of algebra (and trig) before you even step foot on a college campus.
